Subject: Urgent: Written Confirmation Needed for No Mail Request & Clarification on Service Issues

Dear [Service Provider's Name],

I hope this message finds you well. I appreciate your attempt to reach out and discuss the concerns I raised in my initial complaint. However, as I mentioned previously, I'm currently unable to manage phone calls to deliberate on these issues. Communicating via email is not only most convenient for me at this time but also allows for a clear, documented trail of our interactions, which is important for both parties to ensure that all issues are accurately addressed and resolved.

Regarding your request for a discussion about the "inattentiveness" and the statement that there seem to be no incomplete requests in your system, I want to clarify what has transpired from my perspective. My primary and most urgent issue, which seems to have been overlooked once again in your response, is the request to cease all mailings to my associated address immediately. This was explicitly stated in my initial complaint and remains unresolved, impacting my view of your service's attentiveness to client requests.

To address your concerns and provide clarity on what I've found inattentive, here are the specifics:

1. **Repeated Requests Ignored**: My request to stop all postal mail to the provided address has been made multiple times now, with no acknowledgment or action taken on your part.
2. **Lack of Response to Emails**: Prior to this, there have been instances where my emails regarding service adjustments or queries were either not responded to promptly or were completely ignored.
3. **System Discrepancies**: Your statement that there are no incomplete requests in my account contrasts sharply with my experiences and the unresolved issues mentioned.

Given these points, I kindly request that we proceed with resolving the most immediate concern – the stoppage of all mail to my address. I need written confirmation that this request will be acted upon immediately. Once we've successfully navigated this issue, I am more than willing to detail further any other areas that might help improve your service based on my experiences.

I understand the importance of communication and am committed to finding a resolution. While I recognize that phone conversations can sometimes expedite this process, I believe we can achieve the same level of clarity and resolution through written correspondence. 

Thank you for your understanding and prompt attention to these matters. I look forward to your written confirmation regarding the cessation of mail to my address and any insights you might have on how we can address the broader service concerns I've outlined.

Warm regards,

[Your Name]

Fitzgerald’s use of irony not only articulates Gatsby’s internal conflict but also reflects a broader, detailed analysis of 1920s American culture. The novel’s society is mired in paradoxes: vast, lively parties offer a veneer of communal joy, yet individuals find themselves ensnared in webs of loneliness and isolation — an idea earlier distilled in the antithesis of “large parties are so intimate.” Just as sprawling celebrations are ironically the settings for personal alienation, Gatsby’s grandiose dream results in a hauntingly vacuous reality. Thus, irony becomes a vital literary instrument in Fitzgerald’s repertoire, enabling him to accentuate the disparity between appearance and essence, weaving a narrative rich in depth and commentary. It lays bare the era’s cultural ethos, where individuals are perpetually navigating the dissonance between the American Dream’s lustrous facade and its deeply flawed, often sorrowful incarnation.

In "The Great Gatsby," Fitzgerald deftly captures not just the personal struggles of Gatsby himself, but paints a vivid canvas of the 1920s in America. He shows us a world caught in contradictions: the grand and noisy parties give off the illusion of shared happiness, but peel back the layers and you'll find people trapped in their own private worlds of solitude. It's like when Fitzgerald says big parties have an unexpected intimacy—it's the perfect contrast showing us the truth behind the façade. As these epic celebrations serve as backdrops for feelings of disconnect, Gatsby’s own magnificent aspirations crumble into an empty pit of reality. Irony, for Fitzgerald, isn't just a tool; it's the brush he uses to highlight the gap between what seems to be and what truly is, stitching together a story with real depth and social critique. This tactic starkly exposes the cultural mindset of the time: people endlessly trying to reconcile the shiny, attractive image of the American Dream with its deeply embedded imperfections and often heartache-filled real-life counterpoint.

	Dr. T.J. Eckleburg’s billboard represents symbolism as a literary device in The Great Gatsby. There are a couple ideas that the billboard represents, first is that it is all seeing over all of the wrongdoings of the book, when George Wilson was confronting his wife Myrtle for cheating on him with Tom. He took her to a window that had the billboard with the eyes and said: “God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me but you can't fool God!” (170). Which implied that the billboard was watching over the acts of Myrtle with Tom through God’s omniscient eyes. Humans seeking their fortune will do misdoings in order to get what they want. In “The Great Gatsby,” the billboard serves as a potent and significant emblem. It witnesses each unethical deed and peers beneath the deceit perpetuated by the characters, from affairs with others to the pretenses of their achievements. Each individual in the narrative appears to conceal a sinister secret, and the ever-observant eyes of the billboard vigilantly monitor the concealed schemes at play.
	In the first page of The Great Gatsby under the title Fitzgerald uses an literary device Epigraph, “Then wear the gold hat, if that will move her; If you can bounce high, bounce for her too, Till she cries ‘Lover, gold-hatted, high-bouncing lover, I must have you!” (1). The poem creates context for Gatzby’s monomaniacal goal for capturing Daisy's heart. It also exposes important information for future events of the book such as Gatsby trying to win over Daisy by impressing her with money, luxury, and buying a mansion on the other side of her beach. The poem can be interpreted as a reflection on how the protagonist, Jay Gatsby, will go to capture the attention and affection of his beloved, Daisy Buchanan. It speaks to the idea of doing whatever it takes, even if it means showing off and being flamboyant, to win the heart of the person one loves. 
Fitzgerald’s use of irony not only articulates Gatsby’s internal conflict but also reflects a broader, detailed analysis of 1920’s American culture. The society in which this novel takes place reads in paradoxes: vast, lively parties offer a cover of communal joy, yet the individuals find themselves trapped in a web of loneliness — an idea earlier distilled in the antithesis of  “large parties are so intimate” (54). Just as the celebrations are the settings for personal alienation.  Thus, irony becomes an instrument in Fitzgerald’s book, helping him accentuate the disparity between appearance and essence, such as the moment in the book where no one went to everyone went to his Grand parties but everyone went to Gatsby's funeral. It lays bare the era’s cultural spirit, where individuals are forever navigating the dissonance between the American Dream’s lustrous facade and its deeply flawed, often sorrowful incarnation.

Accurately depicting the extent of paleoclimate change in the western edge of the northern Gondwana passive margin and related Intrarif-Mesorif-Prerif sub-domains, which possess several attributes of a “paleo-Critical Zone” as defined by Nordt et al. (2012) and Ashley et al. (2020), characterized by a complex interplay between various Earth subsystems (Hyland and Sheldon, 2016) during the Jurassic period is a daunting challenge due to significant unresolved scientific issues. The primary objective of this study is multi-faceted and aimed at providing new insights and clear constraints on the paleoclimate and related Earth processes. Additionally, we aim to evaluate and understand chemical weathering mechanisms and the efficient transfer of fluxes from source to sink under altered climatic conditions, assess the paleo-redox conditions and related depositional palaeoenvironments and paleoproductivity, enhance our comprehension of the floral landscape and related paleogeography based on the geochemistry record of the sedimentary rocks, and contextualize the obtained data within regional and global frameworks. This comprehensive study aims to contribute to a more thorough and nuanced understanding of paleoclimate change in this critical region, and provide valuable insights to the broader scientific community.

The variation of Earth’s surface landscape throughout geological time results from the interplay of intrinsic and extrinsic forces, and both are controlled by first-order tectonic plate geodynamics under varying climatic conditions. Understanding this interplay is crucial for determining the evolution of Earth’s surface processes and predicting future climate change scenarios. The balance between intrinsic and extrinsic forces triggers the uplift of orogens and connected subsiding basins, and the denudation of the built orogen’s relief. It is therefore important to track the Earth’s past climate change and understand its interaction with Earth’s subsystems, including the geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere, from source to sink. This knowledge will help to better understand the evolution of Earth’s surface processes and their complex interactions with Earth’s subsystems through geological time and to predict future climate change scenarios (see Tierney et al., 2020).
The scientific community is now showing worldwide interest in climate change and its impact on the geological record as it can better constrain our knowledge on the topic. Although the early alpine history during the Jurassic of prominent landform plate assemblages is well known, little data regarding their climate and related climate-process systems are available. Therefore, further research is necessary to enhance our knowledge of the Jurassic climate, mainly in areas belonging to the northern Gondwana boundary (see Price and Sellwood, 1997; Price and Page, 2008; Riccardi, 1991; Podlaha et al., 1998; Price and Gröcke, 2002; Gröcke et al., 2003; Fürsich et al., 2005; Lécuyer and Bucher, 2006; Jenkyns et al., 2012; Alberti et al., 2012a, b, 2013, 2017; 2019).
Some authors (e.g., Hallam, 1993; Sellwood and Valdes, 2006, 2008; Holz, 2015; Li et al., 2022) consider the Jurassic climate to have been warm, while others (e.g. Dromart et al., 2003; Royer 2006; Bodin et al., 2017, 2020; Krencker et al., 2019; and Scotese et al., 2021) report the occurrence of “cool modes” in the middle Jurassic climate, qualified as “Callovian Ice Age” (e.g. Dromart et al., 2003).
The climate change that occurred during the Jurassic period is of paramount interest as it highlights the climate process systems in the northern boundary of the Gondwana realm. This region was a wide northwestern Gondwana passive margin of the Tethysian realm. Numerous studies have examined climate changes during the Jurassic period. Takashima et al. (2006) discovered that this period was a classical greenhouse era characterized by high atmospheric CO2 concentration. Dera et al. (2011) suggested that the high CO2 concentration provides an appropriate modern-day analogy to better understand climate changes throughout Earth’s history. More recent studies by Tierney et al. (2020), Scotese (2021), Skea et al. (2022), and Burgener et al. (2023) have also aimed to contribute to our understanding of Earth’s climate change over geological time. Such research is crucial for comprehending why and how the climate has changed and for predicting future climate shifts.
The middle Jurassic epoch was a significant geological period marked by major global geological events in Earth’s history (Dera et al., 2011). First-order plate tectonics triggered the final breakup of Pangea and Gondwana, as well as subsequent continental rifting. These events led to the opening of new seaways and the initiation of seafloor spreading in the central Atlantic, the western Tethys, and large-scale oceanic corridors. Bartolini and Larson (2001) and Martini and Ortega-Gutierrez (2018) have provided evidence of this process. Additionally, research by Labails et al. (2010), Dera et al. (2015), and Scotese et al. (2021) has further elucidated the extent and impact of these geological events.
These events occurred concurrently with climate fluctuations that began during the late early Jurassic period. This period was marked by a shift from the late Pliensbachian “cool event” as described by Korte and Hesselbo (2011) and Korte et al. (2015) to the warm Toarcian Oceanic Anoxic Event (TOAE) as documented by Jenkyns (1988), Bailey et al. (2003), Rosales et al. (2004), and Korte et al. (2015). Since the early Aalenian, the climate has shifted back to a cooling event, as reported by Korte et al. (2015).
An important debate has been raised exclusively for the Jurassic climate during the critical middle-late Jurassic transitional period considered by some authors (Norris and Hallam ,1995; Jacquin et al.,1998; Hallam ,2001; Wierzbowski et al. ,2009) as a global warming event, with a significant sea-level rise (Wierzbowski et al., 2009; Wierzbowski and Rogov, 2011), driven by enhanced volcanic activity, tectonic uplift of oceanic ridges, and the reorganization of the seafloor oceanic spreading which increased greenhouse gases considered as a potential source of the atmospheric CO2 concentration raise during thisperiod (Wierzbowski et al., 2009, 2012), and therefore responsible for the climate warming Sellwood and Valdes, (2008); Holz et al., (2015).On the other hand, Dromart et al. (2003); Nunn (2009); Price and Rogov (2009); and Donnadieu et al. (2011) supported an opposite hypothesis suggesting that the middle-late Jurassic transitional period (160 Ma) may correspond to a severe “cooling event” simultaneous with an abrupt global-scale fall of sea level suggestive of continental ice formation at this time and due to a global cooling (Scotese et al., 2021).
The main knowledge accumulated about the Earth is mainly reported from marine records (e.g., Alberti et al., 2020). Here, we are more interested in the middle Jurassic climate of mid-latitude provinces where seawater temperatures were cool (about 10°C), occurring coevally with the northern Sea Dome in the southern part of the Viking Corridor. This dome was responsible for large-scale volcanic activity, impacting oceanic circulation by preventing the equatorial warm oceanic current from reaching the Northern Polar region (Korte et al., 2015).
To forecast the Earth’s surface processes under Jurassic climate change in the northern African passive margin, a combination of different geochemical proxies (including major, trace, and rare earth elements) and clay mineralogy have been utilized. This approach aims to better assess weathering intensity, chemical variations, and sediment supply from continental sources to neighboring oceanic sinks under Jurassic paleoclimatic conditions. Such conditions can impact sediment and organic matter redistribution in the oceanic sink, particularly by the near-surface hydrological source to sink processes.
In order to accurately depict the extent of paleoclimate change in the western edge of the northern Gondwana passive margin and related Intrarif-Mesorif-Prerif sub-domains, which possess several attributes of a “paleo-Critical Zone” as defined by Nordt et al. (2012) and Ashley et al. (2020), characterized by a complex interplay between various Earth subsystems (Hyland and Sheldon, 2016) during the Jurassic period, where significant scientific issues still remain unresolved, the primary objective of this study is multi-layered and aimed at: (i) providing new insights and clear constraints on the paleoclimate and related Earth processes, (ii) evaluating and understanding chemical weathering mechanisms, as well as the efficient transfer of fluxes from source to sink under altered climatic conditions, (iii) assessing the paleo-redox conditions and related depositional palaeoenvironments and paleoproductivity, (iv) enhancing our comprehension of the floral landscape and related paleogeography based on the geochemistry record of the sedimentary rocks, and (v) contextualizing the obtained data within regional and global frameworks.

John 14:28 explanation

John 14:28 is a verse from the Bible, found in the Gospel of John, which reads: "You heard me say to you, 'I am going away, and I will come to you.' If you loved me, you would have rejoiced, because I am going to the Father, for the Father is greater than I." This verse is part of Jesus’ farewell discourse to His disciples, delivered during the Last Supper and before His crucifixion.

The verse contains several key points for reflection and analysis:

1. **Jesus’ Departure and Return**: Jesus is preparing His disciples for His imminent departure - His death, resurrection, and ascension. The phrase "I am going away, and I will come to you" refers to His promise to be with them spiritually and to His eventual return at the Second Coming.

2. **Call to Rejoice**: Jesus suggests that if His disciples truly loved Him, they would rejoice at the prospect of His departure. This seems counterintuitive because one would expect sadness at the departure of a loved one. However, Jesus points towards the greater good of His mission – His death and resurrection are necessary for salvation, and His return to the Father is a part of the divine plan for humanity’s redemption.

3. **The Relationship Between Jesus and the Father**: The statement "the Father is greater than I" has been the subject of much theological discussion. It reflects the complex Christian teaching on the Trinity - God as Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, three distinct persons but one essence. In His incarnation as a human, Jesus willingly submits to the Father, acknowledging the Father’s authority. This does not imply inequality in their divine nature but rather describes their relational roles within the Godhead and Jesus' voluntary submission and humility in His human nature.

In summary, John 14:28 offers deep insights into the nature of Jesus’ mission, His relationship with God the Father, and how His followers are to understand His departure. It emphasizes faith, the fulfillment of God's plan through Jesus’ sacrifice, and the joy believers can find in the ultimate victory that Jesus’ return to the Father represents.
John 10:29 explanation

John 10:29 is a passage from the Gospel of John in the New Testament of the Christian Bible. The verse says, "My Father, who has given them to me, is greater than all; no one can snatch them out of my Father’s hand." This verse is part of a larger discourse where Jesus is describing Himself as the good shepherd who knows His sheep, and whose sheep know Him. In this context, "them" refers to Jesus' followers or believers.

Here's a deeper look into the meaning and implications of this verse:

1. **Divine Gift**: The phrase "My Father, who has given them to me," suggests that believers are a gift from the Father to the Son. This emphasizes the divine plan and election, indicating that followers of Jesus are chosen by God and given to Christ. It underscores the intimate relationship between the Father, the Son, and believers.

2. **God’s Sovereignty and Protection**: By stating that the Father is "greater than all," the verse speaks to the absolute sovereignty and power of God. There is none greater than God the Father in terms of authority, power, and supremacy. This is a reassurance to the believers of the unmatched protection they are under.

3. **Security of Believers**: The promise that "no one can snatch them out of my Father’s hand" is a powerful assurance of eternal security for believers. It indicates that once a person becomes a follower of Jesus, they are under the protective authority of God the Father, from which no external force or entity can remove them. This is often understood to mean that the salvation and eternal life that believers have in Jesus are secure and cannot be lost or taken away by any force or circumstance.

This verse, therefore, offers comfort and assurance to followers of Jesus, communicating the depth of God's love, the strength of His protection, and the certainty of their salvation. It reassures believers of their value to God and the eternal security they have through their faith in Jesus Christ. The passage highlights the intimate and unbreakable relationship between the Father, the Son, and their followers, grounded in divine love, power, and purpose.

Green training and development refers to the process of equipping employees with working approaches that ensure adequate resource utilisation, reduce waste, energy conservation, and environmental degradation. Performance of the organization is also associated with the green training and development of employees because training incorporates knowledge and skills in the employees needed to achieve organizational goals and objectives of sustainability. A study has shown that GHRM variables, including green recruitment, green training and development and green learning on firm performance significantly affect the performance of the firm (Bhutto &Auranzeb, 2016). Furthermore, green training has been identified as one of the influential practices of human resource development (HRD) which helps to develop the green behaviour, thus contributing to the effective and efficient business performance of a firm.

Green education and training encompass the initiation of employees into practices that promote efficient use of resources, waste minimization, energy saving, and the prevention of environmental harm. The effectiveness of an organization is also linked to its green education and training programs, as such initiatives instill essential knowledge and capabilities in employees, enabling them to meet the organization's sustainability goals and targets. Research indicates that Green Human Resource Management (GHRM) aspects, such as green hiring, green education and training, and green knowledge dissemination, have a notable impact on a company's success (Bhutto & Auranzeb, 2016). Additionally, green education is recognized as a pivotal aspect of human resource development (HRD), fostering environmentally friendly behaviors among employees, thereby enhancing a company's operational efficiency and performance.

Rewards and compensation are the major HRM processes through which employees are rewarded for their performance. These HR practices are the most powerful methods, which links together an individual’s interest to that of the organization’s. In the context of Green HRM, rewards and compensation can be assumed as potential tools for supporting environmental activities in organizations. Green rewards can include the use of workplace and lifestyle benefits, ranging from carbon credit offsets to free bicycles, engaging people in the green agenda and continuing to recognize their contribution (Pillai & Sivathanu, 2014). Modern organizations are developing reward systems to encourage eco-friendly initiatives embarked upon by their employees. It has been observed that employee commitment to environment management programs was increased when they were offered compensation to take up duties in relation to environmental responsibility. Green rewards lead to the highest level of job satisfaction, which significantly enhances the environmental performance (Lawler & Porter, 2008). The usage of rewards and recognition on the basis of environmental sustainability places a positive impact on the motivation of employees to experiment green initiatives (Ramus, 2001). Thus as a result of improved employees commitment and motivation, the performance of the business will be improved as employees have been motivated to work through green reward and compensation initiatives in the Organisation.

Compensation and rewards serve as crucial mechanisms within Human Resource Management (HRM) for recognizing employee achievements. These HR strategies are among the most effective for aligning the interests of individuals with those of their organization. Within the scope of Green HRM, compensation and rewards emerge as influential levers to endorse pro-environmental endeavors within firms. Green incentives may span various workplace and personal lifestyle perks, such as carbon offset credits and complimentary bicycles, thereby actively involving employees in environmental initiatives and appreciating their efforts (Pillai & Sivathanu, 2014). Contemporary firms are tailoring their incentive schemes to promote environmentally responsible actions undertaken by their staff. It has been noted that a rise in employee engagement with environmental management efforts correlates with their receiving incentives for assuming environmentally responsible roles. The introduction of green incentives has been directly linked to increased job satisfaction levels, which, in turn, significantly boost a company's environmental achievements (Lawler & Porter, 2008). Rewarding and recognizing employees based on their contributions to environmental sustainability has been shown to positively influence their willingness to pursue green projects (Ramus, 2001). Consequently, the bolstered commitment and motivation of employees, driven by green compensation and reward schemes, enhance organizational performance as employees are spurred to adopt green practices.

Performance management is a process in which the employees are encouraged to enhance their professional skills to better achieve organisational goals. Obaid et al. (2015) noted that an increase in Green performance management results in an increase in the effectiveness of the organization. Furthermore, the motivation of green employees’ passion involves activities like green performance management and green reward & pay systems (Pellegrini et al., 2018). The most important aspect of PM is performance appraisal. In addition to meeting the criteria of reliability, validity, and fairness, effective performance appraisals provide useful feedback to employees and support continuous improvements in the firm’s environmental outcomes, thus leading to improving the business operations and performance.  Green performance management and incentives policies can assist employers in aligning employee behaviour with the corporate environmental objectives. Additionally, green performance management is an excellent technique to increase employee environmental engagement and hence their readiness to commit in eco-friendly innovation.

The performance management system is designed to motivate employees to refine their professional abilities, thereby contributing more effectively to organizational objectives. Obaid et al. (2015) observed that an enhancement in Green performance management practices correlates with an increase in organizational efficiency. Additionally, igniting the enthusiasm of employees towards environmental sustainability can involve strategies like green performance management and environmentally-focused reward and compensation schemes (Pellegrini et al., 2018). A critical element of performance management is the performance evaluation process. Effective performance appraisals go beyond achieving the standards of reliability, validity, and fairness; they offer constructive feedback to employees, fostering ongoing enhancements in the company's environmental performance, thereby elevating overall business operations and results. The implementation of green performance management and incentive strategies is crucial in guiding employee actions towards meeting the environmental goals of the company. Moreover, incorporating green performance management practices is an effective approach to boost employees' engagement with environmental initiatives, increasing their willingness to partake in sustainable innovations.

The green health and safety management is really beyond the scope of traditional health and safety management function of HRM. It really includes the traditional health and safety management and some more aspects of environmental management of an organization. The key role of green health and safety management is to ensure a green workplace for all. A safe and healthy working environment is vital for overall sustainability, due to the fact that it affects opportunities of economic and social development. Occupational safety and health system with effective and efficient framework for the workforce can help minimize and prevent workplace accidents, injuries, hazard, medical illnesses and death. Furthermore, some proactive companies in environmental management found that management of environment helps in improvements in the health of employees and local communities, enhancing the image of the company as a desirable employer and corporate citizen (Stringer, 2009).

Green health and safety management extends well past the traditional boundaries of the health and safety management function within Human Resource Management (HRM). It encompasses both the customary aspects of health and safety management and additional components of an organization's environmental management practices. The principal objective of green health and safety management is to create a green, safe, and healthy workplace environment for everyone. Maintaining a secure and wholesome working environment is crucial for the broader sustainability agenda, given its significant impact on the possibilities for economic and social advancement. An occupational safety and health system that is both effective and efficient serves to reduce and avert workplace mishaps, injuries, hazards, medical illnesses, and fatalities. Additionally, it has been observed by forward-thinking companies engaged in environmental management that focusing on environmental aspects leads to improvements in the health of both employees and local communities, further elevating the company's reputation as an appealing employer and responsible corporate entity (Stringer, 2009).

Green Employee relation is the HR practice concerned with establishing harmonious employer–employee interaction towards attaining environmental sustainability. As per researchers, Green Employee Relations practices include -“involving employees in green practices, joint consultations in resolving environmental issues, introducing green whistle-blowing and help lines (Renwick et al., 2013), providing training to the union representatives in environmental management and negotiating with trade unions on environmental issues.”When there is a smooth employer- employee relations in the organisation, the performance of such business and its operations tend to improve. Improved employee morale, stronger public image, increased consumer/ customer confidence, employee loyalty and brand recognition, position as an employer of choice, increased workforce productivity, efficiency, motivation and employee retention are few of the many advantages and benefits an organization can have by implementing and developing a green employee relations in the organization.

Green Employee Relations constitutes an HR practice aimed at fostering positive interactions between employers and employees with a focus on achieving environmental sustainability. Researchers suggest that practices within Green Employee Relations encompass involving employees in eco-friendly initiatives, collaborative discussions to address environmental challenges, the establishment of green whistle-blowing mechanisms and support lines (Renwick et al., 2013), training for union representatives on environmental management, and engaging in negotiations with trade unions concerning environmental matters. When employer-employee relationships are harmonious within an organization, it often leads to enhanced performance of the business and its operational activities. The adoption and cultivation of green employee relations within an organization can yield numerous benefits, including but not limited to, heightened employee morale, an improved public image, greater confidence from consumers/customers, enhanced employee loyalty and brand recognition, establishing the organization as a preferred employer, and marked increases in workforce productivity, efficiency, motivation, and retention.

2.5.8.2 Return on Equity   
 Return on equity (ROE) is a measure of financial performance in the manufacturing industries, which can be calculated by dividing net income by shareholders' equity. Because shareholders' equity is equal to a company’s assets minus its debt, ROE is considered the return on net assets. ROE is considered a measure of how effectively management is using a company’s assets to create profits.
2.5.8.3 Return on Investment
Return on Investment (ROI) is a performance measure used to evaluate the efficiency of an investment or compare the efficiency of a number of different investments at manufacturing industries.  To calculate ROI, the benefit (or return) of an investment is divided by the cost of the investment. The result is expressed as a percentage or a ratio. 2.5.8.2 Equity Return Ratio
Equity Return Ratio, or Return on Equity (ROE), serves as an indicator of financial success within the manufacturing sector, obtained by dividing the net profit by the shareholders' equity. Given that shareholders' equity is the difference between a company's assets and its liabilities, ROE is essentially regarded as the return on the company's net assets. This metric is a reflection of how efficiently a company's management is leveraging its assets to generate earnings.

2.5.8.3 Investment Return Measure
Investment Return Measure, commonly known as Return on Investment (ROI), assesses the profitability of an investment or compares the efficacies of several investments within the manufacturing domain. The formula for ROI involves dividing the gain from an investment by the investment's initial cost, with the outcome represented as a percentage or ratio. The implementation of green human resource management practices has been shown to bolster ROI in the manufacturing sectors by enhancing transparency, accountability, and integrity.

2.5.8.4 Capital Utilization Return
Capital Utilization Return, or Return on Capital Employed (ROCE), is a financial metric employed to evaluate a firm's profitability and efficiency in capital use. This indicator is instrumental in illustrating how effectively a company generates profits using its capital, which is particularly relevant for improving service delivery and ensuring accountability within the manufacturing industries.

This chapter discussed the research methods and analytical technique that was employed in carrying out the study. It also deals with the research design, which highlights how the study was conducted and analysed for the study. It explains the population and sampling technique used in this study. This chapter justifies the choice of the research design and provides information on the data source as well as methods of data collection and data analysis technique employed.

This segment of the document delves into the methodology and analytical approaches utilized throughout the research process. It further encompasses the research framework, detailing the procedural and analytical strategies embraced for this investigation. An explanation of both the population under study and the sampling method applied is included herein. This section substantiates the selection of the research methodology and furnishes insight into the origins of the data, alongside the methodologies for data acquisition and the analytical techniques implemented.

The descriptive ex-post-facto research design adopted. An ex-post-facto research design is considered appropriate and suitable for this study because it is capable of examining the cause-effect relationship between the green human resource management and business performance of manufacturing industries in South-West, Nigeria. The ex-post facto research design is also appropriate for the study because manipulation of the data and research process by the researcher could not be made possible since the event under the study had already occurred. In essence, the respondents were allowed to express their views without any direct or indirect influence of the research in the study.
Besides, the ex-post-facto research design was adopted because it afford the researcher the opportunity to collect existing data; and describe the situation as it is in the present form, and not as it was. The ex-post-facto research design was appropriate for the study because it afford the all respondents the equal chance of participation in the study. Besides, the ex-post-facto research design was considered most relevant to this study because a large amount of data were gathered for analysis and interpretation using the appropriate statistical methods.

The research employed a descriptive ex-post-facto design. This design was deemed fit and appropriate for the investigation as it efficiently facilitates the exploration of cause-effect relationships between green human resource management practices and the performance of manufacturing industries in South-West Nigeria. The choice of an ex-post-facto design was further justified as it precludes the possibility of data and process manipulation by the researcher, given that the events of interest have already taken place. Therefore, it allowed participants to share their perspectives freely, without any direct or indirect influence from the study’s conduct.

Moreover, the ex-post-facto design was selected for its capability to enable the researcher to leverage existing data, providing a depiction of the current state of affairs rather than a historical account. This design was advantageous for the study as it guaranteed an equal opportunity for all participants to contribute. Additionally, the ex-post-facto approach was considered most suitable for this research due to its capacity to facilitate the collection of a substantial volume of data, which was then analyzed and interpreted through appropriate statistical methodologies.

The population of this study consists of all staff in the selected manufacturing industries that are operating in the three States in South-West, Nigeria. Thus, the current staff strength of the selected manufacturing companies stood at forty nine thousand, eight hundred and thirty three (49,833). Specifically, the branch Managers, the Assistant Managers, branch Accountants, Senior and Middle levels staff in the selected manufacturing industries serves as respondents for the study. Most importantly, both males and females staff shall participate in this study. However, only employees that are working with the selected manufacturing industries in South-West, Nigeria serve as the target population for the study.

The study's target population encompasses all employees from the chosen manufacturing companies operational across three states in the South-West region of Nigeria. The current total number of staff members across these selected firms is forty-nine thousand, eight hundred and thirty-three (49,833). More precisely, individuals holding positions such as Branch Managers, Assistant Managers, Branch Accountants, and other staff at senior and middle levels within these manufacturing entities are identified as respondents for this investigation. It is imperative to note that this study is inclusive of both male and female staff members. Nevertheless, the focal group for this study is strictly limited to those individuals who are employed by the selected manufacturing companies situated in South-West Nigeria, thereby defining the study's target population.

A total of 2,492 respondents were selected for the study using the purposive and proportionate stratified sampling technique. The simple random sampling technique was used to select the employees for the study. Purposive sampling was adopted because of the need to select manufacturing industries with minimum of ten years listing on the Nigerian Stock Exchange and whose data does not distort the overall panel data of this study. The following Manufacturing Industries that operate on the shore of South-West, Nigeria, are selected for the study:
Nestle Nigeria Plc; Nigerian Breweries Plc, Flour Mills of Nigeria, Cadbury Nigeria Ltd and Unilever Nigeria Plc.
 It is pertinent to note that all the selected manufacturing industries operate in South-West, Nigeria and among the fast growing industries in Nigeria. The choice of purposive sampling technique became necessary since some manufacturing industries did not report their financial affairs in a manner that could enhance data extraction for research purpose. 
Moreover, for the purpose of collecting primary data, the proportionate stratified sampling technique was adopted for selection of respondents from the selected manufacturing industries in South-West, Nigeria. Definitely, there is variation in the number of employees that are presently in the employment of each of the selected manufacturing industries. The proportionate sampling methods were therefore used for selection of respondents to reflect the proportion of population of employees across selected manufacturing industries in South-West, Nigeria.
In summary, a sample size of Two thousand, four hundred and ninety two (2,492) respondents was selected from the universe population using the 5 per cent ratio of the staff strength of the selected manufacturing industries in South-West, Nigeria.

This section elaborates on the exploration of green human resource management (HRM) practices through the utilization of the Green Human Resource Management Questionnaire (GHRMPQ). The GHRMPQ is comprised of seven distinct sub-scales aimed at assessing various facets of green HRM, including green human resource planning; green recruitment and selection; green training and development; green compensation management; green industrial relations; green performance management; and green occupational health and safety initiatives. Developed by Cepeda-Carrión, Ojeda-Benítez, & Aguilera-Caracuel in 2021, this instrument was specifically modified to cater to the aims of this study. Responses were captured using a 4-point Likert scale — Strongly Agree (SA), Agree (A), Disagree (D), and Strongly Disagree (SD). Initially, the questionnaire reported a Cronbach alpha reliability coefficient of 0.78, however, for this particular investigation, the Cronbach alpha increased to 0.89, reflecting enhanced internal consistency.

Additionally, several specific scales were employed to measure different green HRM practices:

1. **Green Human Resource Planning Scale (GHRPS):** This scale, which consists of 6 items, seeks to assess green human resource planning in the context of business performance, utilizing a 4-point Likert scale. While the original Cronbach alpha reported was 0.75, it was recalculated as 0.81 for this study, indicating satisfactory reliability.

2. **Green Recruitment and Selection Scale (GRSS):** Aimed at evaluating green recruitment and selection practices, this scale also relies on a 4-point Likert scale for responses. The initial reliability coefficient was 0.85, but a slightly lower reliability coefficient of 0.83 was observed in this research.

3. **Green Training and Development Scale (GTDS):** Focused on green training and development practices, this scale also used a 4-point Likert response scale. The initially reported Cronbach alpha of 0.81 increased to 0.86 in the current study, suggesting a strong level of internal consistency.

4. **Green Compensation Management Scale (GCMS):** This instrument measures the impact of green compensation management on business performance. Originally reporting a Cronbach alpha of 0.74, this study observed an increase to 0.78.

5. **Green Performance Management Scale (GPMS):** This scale assesses the green performance management practices within an organization. While the reported Cronbach alpha was initially 0.81, it rose to 0.89 for this research, indicating a very reliable instrument for this study's purposes.

Each scale provided invaluable insights into the specific dimensions of green HRM practices and their relation to business performance, demonstrating overall high reliability and relevance to the study's objectives.

The study investigated the impact of green human resource management practices on business performance in manufacturing industries in South-West, Nigeria. The green human resource management examined in the study include (Green recruitment and selection; green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, green performance management and green employee relations management). The study as well identified different performance indicators, they include earning per share; return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on asset, dividend per share, and profit after tax. It is pertinent to note that six objectives were set up for the study.
Objective one, which is to find out the forms and levels of awareness created on green human resource management practices in selected manufacturing industries was analysed using the frequency distribution analysis technique. Finding showed that there is high level of awareness created on green human resource management practices in the selected manufacturing companies. Majority i.e., 1778 (71.2%) of the respondents affirms there is very high and high level of awareness. This finding corroborates Bombiak and Marciniuk-Kluska (2018), who submitted that awareness and dissemination of knowledge concerning green human resource management had have significant impact on sustainable development in work organization.
Objective two seeks to examine the contributions of the combined green human resource management (GHRM) practices to business performance in the selected manufacturing companies. Test of hypothesis one helped to achieve this objective as multiple regression analysis was used to analysis the data collected for this purpose. From the findings, it was discovered that the combine impact of GHRM practices identified in the study which are Green recruitment and selection; Green human resource planning, Green training and development, Green compensation management, Green performance management and Green employee relations management had strong and positive contribution to business performance in the selected manufacturing companies (0.716)  i.e., the GHRM practices identified in the study had 71.6% combined influence on business performance. More so, finding revealed a positive contribution, which denotes that has the GHRM practices increase business performance also increases and when it decreases business performance also decreases. 
This finding supports some previous findings by other researchers. For instance, Kanapala and Battu (2018), from their finding revealed that GHRM practices play a vital role promoting corporate environmental performance, which in turn improves employee performance. More so, Zhang, Ma & Song (2021), finding allies with this finding as well, they established a significant relationship between green innovation, green human resource management, and firm performance in China. Shahzad et al. (2019) found that there is a significant relationship between green human resource management practices and environmental sustainability in Pakistani manufacturing firms. Nguyen and Nguyen (2020) established positive impact of green human resource management on environmental management practices and firm performance in Vietnamese firms.
Objective three was to determine the relative contributions of each of the green human resource management practices to business performance. This was achieved testing hypothesis two using multiple regression analysis. Finding showed that all the GHRM practices identified in the study had a significant influence on business performance. The findings also revealed that green training and development had the highest influence on business performance as beta coefficient value showed .229(22.9%), followed by Green recruitment and selection with 0.198(19.8%), then Green compensation management 0.167 (16.7%), then Green performance management 0.147(14.7%) and the least green employee relations management 0.127(12.7%). 
This finding also tallies with the findings of the number of previous studies. Bhutto and Auranzeb, (2016) found that green recruitment, green training and development and green learning on firm performance significantly affect the performance of the firm. Also, Almemari et al. (2021) also showed that there is a positive impact of the green HRM on environmental, economic, and social performance indicators. Chang and Huang (2019), in their study, established strong relationship between GHRM practices and firm performance using survey data from manufacturing firms.

This investigation explores the influence of green human resource management (GHRM) practices on business performance within manufacturing industries located in South-West Nigeria. The scope of GHRM practices reviewed encompasses Green recruitment and selection, Green human resource planning, Green training and development, Green compensation management, Green performance management, and Green employee relations management. Additionally, the study delineates various performance metrics, including earnings per share, return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on assets, dividend per share, and profit after tax, setting forth six objectives for detailed examination.

The initial objective aimed to explore the degree and form of awareness regarding GHRM practices across select manufacturing organizations, employing frequency distribution as the analysis technique. The findings indicate a significant awareness level of GHRM practices among the studied manufacturing firms, with a majority, specifically 1778 (71.2%) respondents, acknowledging a very high to high level of awareness. This outcome aligns with the assertions of Bombiak and Marciniuk-Kluska (2018) regarding the crucial role of awareness and dissemination of GHRM knowledge in driving sustainable organizational development.

The second objective assessed the collective contribution of GHRM practices to the business performance of the selected manufacturing entities. Employing multiple regression analysis for hypothesis one, the study ascertained a substantial, positive correlation between the incorporated GHRM practices and business performance, with these practices accounting for 71.6% of the variance in business performance. This finding resonates with earlier research, such as Kanapala and Battu (2018) who highlighted the significant role of GHRM practices in elevating corporate environmental performance and, consequently, employee performance. Additional studies, including Zhang, Ma & Song (2021), Shahzad et al. (2019), and Nguyen and Nguyen (2020), corroborate the positive impact of GHRM on firm performance and environmental sustainability across various geographical contexts.

The third objective delved into the specific contributions of each GHRM practice to business performance, utilizing multiple regression analysis for hypothesis two. Results demonstrated significant impacts from all GHRM practices under study, with green training and development emerging as the most influential, followed in descending order by Green recruitment and selection, Green compensation management, Green performance management, and Green employee relations management. This outcome is consistent with findings from previous research like Bhutto and Auranzeb (2016) and Almemari et al. (2021), who found positive effects of GHRM practices on various performance dimensions, and Chang and Huang (2019), who established a strong link between GHRM practices and firm performance in manufacturing settings.

The findings corroborate Zhu, Sarkis and Lai (2013), who reported that the green supply chain management innovation diffusion and its relationship to organizational improvement using the Chinese manufacturing firms and found that the diffusion of GSCM innovations positively affects organizational performance, including financial performance and employee productivity. Ng and Burke (2010) carried out an analytical study on the roles of ecocentric and anthropocentric attitudes as predictors of business managers' commitment to environmental protection. They found that GHRM practices positively influence managers' ecocentric attitudes and their commitment to environmental protection. 
Objective four which is to ascertain the relationship between green human resource 
management practices (green recruitment and selection; green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, green employees' relations management) and business performance (earning per share; return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on asset, dividend per share, profit after tax, customer loyalty and corporate reputation) was achieved by testing hypothesis three. The findings revealed that green recruitment and selection; green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, green employees' relations management are all statistically significant business performance (earning per share; return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on asset, dividend per share, and profit after tax, customer loyalty and corporate reputation). Also, finding showed that green recruitment and selection revealed positive correlation with all the variables of business performance and statistically significant at 0.05 level of confidence and that green human resource and planning has positive correlation with all the variables of business performance. The findings corroborate Ghouri, et al (2020), who reported moderating effects of business environment on enhancement of business performance through green human resource management practices. González-Benito & González-Benito (2018), who reported negative relationship between Green human resource management practices and environmental sustainability.
The findings support revealed that green training and development has positive correlation with all the variables of business performance (earning per share; return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on asset, dividend per share, profit after tax, customer loyalty and corporate reputation). The findings of this study support Ahmed & Ahmad (2021) that reported a positive relationship between firm-specific and market factors with moderating effects on return on investment and return on assets. But that green training and development has negative relationship return on investment but statistically significant. The findings of this study support Akintayo (2018),who submitted that green compensation management as negative relationship with EPS and ROI. This means that variance of correlation reduction of 43.1%, and 0.89% exist respectively, The findings further indicate  that green employee relations management has positive relationship with all the variables of business performance. However, the findings further revealed that green employee relations management has negative contribution to ROI and ROA, but all are statistically significant. 
The findings of this study support Aier et al (2018) and Al-Tamimi & Al-Mazrooei (2017), who submitted that return on asset; investment and earnings per share had significant relationship with performance and market value of firms listed on Abu Dhabi securities exchange.
Objective five sought to establish the gender difference in the perception of business performance based on green human resource management. T-test analysis technique was used to test hypothesis four to achieve this objective. Finding revealed that there is no difference between male and female respondents' perception of business performance based on green human resource management practices. Both male and female have the same perception of business performance geared as a result of GHRM practices. The result from the analysis showed that the variances of the two groups are not different. The findings tally with Atanasovski, et al (2019); Alnaser  & Al-Shattarat (2019), Chatterjee & Chakraborty (2021) and Azizi & Kermani (2017), who reported a significant positive  relationship amongintellectual capital structure, innovation and business  performance.

The results align with Zhu, Sarkis, and Lai (2013) who discovered in their study on green supply chain management innovation diffusion within Chinese manufacturing firms that introducing GSCM innovations considerably enhances organizational outcomes, including both financial performance and employee productivity. Similarly, Ng and Burke (2010) in their analytical investigation into the influence of ecocentric and anthropocentric attitudes on business managers' engagement with environmental protection practices found that GHRM practices have a beneficial impact on managers' ecocentric perspectives and their dedication to environmental conservation.

The fourth objective aimed to establish the connection between green human resource management practices (encompassing green recruitment and selection, green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, and green employee relations management) and various aspects of business performance (such as earnings per share, return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on assets, dividend per share, profit after tax, customer loyalty, and corporate reputation). Through testing the third hypothesis, it was noted that all the green HRM practices examined were significantly related to the different measures of business performance. In particular, green recruitment and selection were found to have a positive correlation with all business performance indicators, being statistically significant at the 0.05 confidence level. These findings find support in Ghouri et al. (2020), who highlighted the moderating role of the business environment in enhancing business performance through GHRM practices, and González-Benito & González-Benito (2018), who noted a complex relation between GHRM and environmental sustainability.

Further, the study revealed that green training and development positively correlate with every aspect of business performance examined. This supports findings by Ahmed & Ahmad (2021), who demonstrated a positive relationship between specific firm and market factors, including the moderating effects on investment returns and asset returns, though green training and development presented an adverse relationship with investment returns, which was, nonetheless, statistically significant. Similarly, Akintayo (2018) found a negative correlation between green compensation management and both EPS and ROI, indicating correlations of reduced strength by 43.1% and 0.89%, respectively. Additionally, green employee relations management was positively linked to all measures of business performance, despite negative contributions to ROI and ROA, yet these were statistically significant.

The study's findings also resonate with those of Aier et al. (2018) and Al-Tamimi & Al-Mazrooei (2017), who confirmed a significant relationship between returns on assets, investment, and earnings per share with the performance and market value of firms listed on the Abu Dhabi securities exchange.

The fifth objective sought to explore gender differences in perceptions of business performance influenced by GHRM practices. Utilizing a T-test to assess this aspect, it was found there was no perceptible difference between the viewpoints of male and female participants regarding business performance driven by GHRM practices. Both genders exhibited a unified perception towards business performance resulting from GHRM initiatives. This result is in accord with previous studies like Atanasovski et al. (2019), Alnaser & Al-Shattarat (2019), Chatterjee & Chakraborty (2021), and Azizi & Kermani (2017), who also acknowledged a significant positive relationship between intellectual capital structure, innovation, and business performance.

Objective Six, which was designed to ascertain the moderating effect of the business natural environment on relationship between green human resource management practices and business performance. This objective was achieved with the testing of hypothesis five with the aid of hierarchical regression. The findings indicate that the variable of green recruitment and Selection explained positive relationship of 22 percent with business performance. The second block (green recruitment and selection, green training, and development) reflected an increased positive relationship with business performance compared with only first block to 28.2%. Findings further revealed that the combination of green recruitment and Selection, green training, and development increased the relationship to 0.28.9% . When block four (green employee relation management) was included with the previous three variables (green recruitment and Selection, green training, and development, green human resource planning), the level of relationship with business performance was increased 32.9%. The finding corroborate Ahmed & Rafiq (2018) and Almemari, et al (2021),who reported positive relationship between green human resource management and sustainable business performance of the manufacturing companies Moreover, the inclusions of green compensation management to the previous four variables (green recruitment and Selection, green training, and development, green human resource planning, green employee relation management), the finding revealed a moderate relationship moderately with increase to 33.1%.  At the last block, the moderating variable (Business natural environment) was introduced to control the level of relationship with the previous five variables, the effect of this moderating variable was so significant in the relationship with business performance as the adjusted R2 increased to 40%. The findings of this study support Badruddoza et al (2018); Chang & Huang (2019) and Ercantan & Eyupoglu (2022),who reported that green human resource management practices has significantly contributed to business performance and encourage employees to engage in green behaviour.

The sixth objective was established to evaluate the moderating impact of the business's natural environment on the nexus between green human resource management (GHRM) practices and business performance. Accomplished through the application of hierarchical regression to test hypothesis five, the findings revealed that green recruitment and selection independently fostered a 22 percent positive association with business performance. Upon integrating the second block, which combines green recruitment and selection with green training and development, the analysis noted an elevation in the positive relationship with business performance to 28.2%, as opposed to the first block alone. Further examination showed that adding green training and development to green recruitment and selection bolstered the connection to business performance by 28.9%.

Subsequently, the integration of the fourth block (green employee relations management) alongside the prior three aspects (green recruitment and selection, green training and development, green human resource planning) amplified the relationship strength with business performance to 32.9%. These observations align with insights from Ahmed & Rafiq (2018) and Almemari et al. (2021), who acknowledged a positive correlation between GHRM and the sustainable business performance of manufacturing firms. Moreover, the inclusion of green compensation management with the preceding four variables (green recruitment and selection, green training and development, green human resource planning, green employee relations management) indicated a modest enhancement in the relationship, rising slightly to 33.1%.

The incorporation of the final block, the moderating variable of the business's natural environment, significantly transformed the dynamic, underlining the profound impact of this moderator on the relationship with business performance as evidenced by the adjusted R^2 escalating to 40%. These outcomes are corroborated by the research of Badruddoza et al. (2018), Chang & Huang (2019), and Ercantan & Eyupoglu (2022), who demonstrated that GHRM practices substantially contribute to business performance enhancement and bolster employee involvement in pro-environmental behaviors.

The examination of previous studies on green human resource management practices and business performance revealed that green HRM practices, such as green recruitment and selection, green training and development, and green performance appraisal, positively impact environmental sustainability. A study by Zhu et al. (2019) further identified the moderating effect of green innovation. This study therefore examined the impact of green human resources management practices on business performance of selected manufacturing companies in Nigeria. 
The study concluded that green human resources practices (Green recruitment and selection; green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, green performance management and green employee relations management) have a positive and significant impact on business performance (earning per share; return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on asset, dividend per share, and profit after tax)of manufacturing companies in South-west, Nigeria. The study concluded that employees in the selected organisation are not novice to green human resources practices. This denotes that the green HRM practices are actually carried out in the companies. 
It was also concluded that green training and development as a green HRM practices has higher impact on business performance than other green HRM practices identified in the study and the green HRM practice with the least impact is green employee relation management. It was also concluded that both male and female employee have the same perception of business performance based on green human resource management practices.

A review of prior research into green human resource management (GHRM) practices and their influence on business performance has disclosed that such practices, including green recruitment and selection, green training and development, and green performance evaluations, have a beneficial effect on environmental sustainability. Notably, a study conducted by Zhu et al. (2019) unveiled the moderating role of green innovation within this context. Consequently, the current research was undertaken to scrutinize the effect of GHRM practices on the business performance of specific manufacturing enterprises in Nigeria.

The findings of this research demonstrated that GHRM practices, encompassing Green recruitment and selection, green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, green performance management, and green employee relations management, exert a positive and marked influence on several facets of business performance, such as earnings per share, return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on assets, dividend per share, and profit after tax, within manufacturing entities situated in South-west Nigeria. The study inferred that employees within the scrutinized organizations are well-acquainted with GHRM practices, indicating the actual implementation of these practices within said companies.

Moreover, it was deduced that among the various GHRM practices examined, green training and development wields a more substantial impact on business performance compared to the others, while green employee relations management ranked as the practice with the minimal influence. Additionally, the study concluded that there is no disparity in perception towards business performance influenced by GHRM practices between male and female employees, signifying a uniform understanding of GHRM practices' impact on business performance across genders.

Based on the finding on the influence of green human resource management practices, the study recommended that more emphasis should be placed on green training and development programmes for employees. Employees should be adequately educated on the importance of environmental management to efficient business performance. In essence, employees should be trained in working methods that conserve energy, reduce waste, diffuse environmental awareness within the organisation, and provide opportunity to engage employees on environmental problem-solving. More so, for improvement of company’s reputation, the management should intensify their efforts in sustainable green training and development programmes. 
The study also recommends that employee relation management should be strengthened as study have shown that green employee relation management has a positive relationship with all performance metrics examined in the study. 
Green recruitment and selection revealed to have 22% relationship with business performance, hence green recruitment and selection process in the selected manufacturing organisation should be improved. 
The study also recommends that in order to increase returns on asset in the selected manufacturing companies, more emphasis should be placed on green compensation management.

Drawing from the findings on the impact of green human resource management (GHRM) practices, the study put forward several recommendations aimed at augmenting business performance through environmental sustainability initiatives. Among the key recommendations is a greater focus on green training and development programs for employees. It is critical that employees are thoroughly informed about the significance of environmental management in enhancing business efficiency. Specifically, the workforce should receive training on practices that minimize energy consumption, reduce wastage, spread environmental consciousness within the organization, and offer avenues for employee involvement in resolving environmental issues. Additionally, to bolster the company's reputation further, management should escalate their commitment to sustainable green training and development initiatives.

The survey also underscored the necessity to strengthen employee relations management. This recommendation is driven by the observation that green employee relations management maintains a positive correlation with all the performance indicators evaluated in the study. This finding suggests that enhancing green employee relations management could contribute significantly to improving overall business performance metrics.

Furthermore, green recruitment and selection were found to have a 22% correlation with business performance, highlighting the need for optimizing the green recruitment and selection processes within the selected manufacturing organizations. By placing a heightened emphasis on attracting and selecting individuals who are not only skillful but also environmentally conscious, companies can ensure a workforce that is aligned with sustainability goals.

Lastly, the study advises that to achieve higher returns on assets, selected manufacturing companies should prioritize green compensation management. Implementing compensation strategies that reward environmentally friendly practices and achievements can incentivize employees to adopt and maintain sustainable behaviors, leading to improved environmental and financial outcomes for the organization.

The study examined the impact of green human resource management practices on business performance in manufacturing industries in South-West, Nigeria, which is a developing economy; unlike previous studies, which centred on developed economies. More so, majority of the previous studies focused on the GHRM practices on environmental sustainability, however, this study contributed to existing literature by establishing GHRM practices on performance of business organisation by focusing on the manufacturing industry. 
Besides, the study has contributed to knowledge by developing a functional conceptual model that established nexus among green human resource management metrics and business performance metrics as examined in the study with loophole feedback mechanism. The conceptual framework developed for the study has provided operational synergy that could propel environmental friendly human resource management practices at the workplace. 
Another contribution of the study to knowledge is in term of variables identified. This study took further steps from previous studies by evaluating a number of GHRM practices, which include green recruitment and selection; green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, green performance management and green employee relations management. More so, on business performance, this study contributed to knowledge by identifying and evaluating, quite a number of performance metrics, such as earning per share; return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on asset, dividend per share, and profit after tax. 
Finally, the study used canonical correlation to measure the multiple variables on independent and dependent variables, which is quite novel and different from an analytical tool used in the previous research works.

This investigation delved into the ramifications of implementing green human resource management (GHRM) practices on the operational effectiveness of manufacturing sectors located in South-West Nigeria, a region situated within a developing economy. This represents a departure from prior research, most of which has been concentrated on developed economies. Furthermore, while a significant portion of these earlier studies was primarily concerned with the impacts of GHRM practices on environmental sustainability, the current study expands the body of existing literature by examining how such practices influence the performance of business organizations, with a particular focus on the manufacturing industry.

Additionally, this study has enriched academic knowledge by formulating a dynamic conceptual model that delineates the relationship between GHRM metrics and business performance indicators, incorporating a loophole feedback mechanism. The conceptual framework devised herein offers an operational synergy that could foster the adoption of environmentally friendly human resource management practices in the workplace.

A further academic contribution of this research lies in its examination of variables. Advancing beyond the scope of prior studies, this investigation assessed an array of GHRM practices, namely green recruitment and selection, green human resource planning, green training and development, green compensation management, green performance management, and green employee relations management. Equally, from the perspective of business performance, this study has augmented the academic discourse by identifying and scrutinizing a comprehensive set of performance metrics, including earnings per share, return on investment, return on equity, return on capital employed, return on asset, dividend per share, and profit after tax.

Lastly, the innovative use of canonical correlation for analyzing the multiple variables across independent and dependent dimensions marks a distinctive methodological approach, setting this study apart from others in the realm of previous research endeavors.

However, the accuracy of conventional radioactive isotope dating gradually decreases as the absolute age of the strata increases.
